editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE IRISH MIMIC; OR BLUNDERS AT BRIGHTON: A MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT IN TWO ACTS.
AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, COVENT-GARDEN.
LONDON: PRINTED FOR T. N. LONGMAN, PATER-NOSTER ROW.

div.head: SCENE I.—A Street.

sp.speaker: COLIN
sp.p: YES, it bes, Harry. Enter Harry in morning dreſs, Trowſers, &c. and bathing man.]

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: No, I ſhan't bathe to-morrow. [Exit man.] Every morning relaxes, and we come down here to brace ourſelves up like drums, for the rattle of a London winter campaign;

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: My brother Harry!

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Colin! what brought you here?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: An if you go to that, what has brought you here?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: I came here but yeſterday with my lady.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Oh, then you got a pleace? So did I the very day after we parted in London.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Why, that's lucky, the firſt week you ſet foot in town.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: No, t'was quite misfortunate. My place was ſo badiſh, Meaſter was one of the ſhew.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: What, an actor.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Yes, he acted your foreign Opera Plays, in Haymarket.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: What! oh, zounds, ha, ha, ha, then, Colin, you was ſervant to an Opera finger?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Yes, that was it; he got a huge deal of money from our high gentry here in England; but to ſave it all, and bring it away with him, he ſtarved himſelf, and gave me nothing to eat: I'll be dom'd but he did, for his ſallads made me pick dandelion, and water creſſes out of the ditches; then he made maccoroni which be's juſt like our hard dumplings cut into long tobacco ſtoppers; then he made omlets, and when he uſed to boil eggs wanted me to ſup the broth, a dom'd Italian ſon of a ſauſage, wanted to fatten me with egg broth, ſo I left him— oh, I left him.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Well, who do you live with? Some Suſſex Squire, Eh?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: No, I bes ſervant to a deſperate voine lady! Miſs Melcomb, from Lancaſhire.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: What! (ſurpriſed) ha! ha! ha! by heavens exceeding good!

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Now your Miſtreſs's name, Harry?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Miſs Melcomb from Lancaſhire.—You impudent puppy, how dare you tell me you live with Miſs Melcomb, when I am certain, I'm the only man ſervant ſhe has at Brighton.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: I ſay I'm her only man ſervant; and dom your impudence, brother Harry! a conceited fool! In his trowſers, ſtrutting about like a pair of compaſſes.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Oh, ſure I've ſeen you before.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Yez, ſir, afore the chair, and behind the coach.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: You live with Miſs Melcomb?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Now mind that Harry, —I do, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: My belov'd here? oh, let me fly!—no, ſhe likes ceremony, my name firſt— (takes out card and writes.)

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: But I muſt go give our cook the Arundel mullets, (goes in houſe.)

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: (turns) Eh, where's Miſs Melcomb's ſervant?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: (advancing) I'm here, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Then you too belong?—ſtep in with this card to your miſtreſs, and bring me back an anſwer; tell her you ſaw her dear Cypreſs, and that I look charming. (Harry goes into diſtinct houſe from Colin, Cypreſs ſeeing him.) Never man had ſuch diſappointments! it's the buſineſs of my life to be kind to my old friends; to be ſure I hope they will leave me ſomething when they die, but no chance of that; here I ſuppoſe they fancy a puff of ſea air can reſtore their breath, and a mouthful of ſalt water pickle and preſerve them, and ecod its no fancy, Tom Nibble that I left in town with one foot in the grave, I met juſt now with two in a pair of boots. Dick Toothleſs that I left ſteep'd in barley broth, I find at Hick's Tavern, peeping at me over a round of beef.—Lady Squab I parted, hid in a ſtuffed elbow chair, I met this morning gallopping over the downs, running a race with a ſtaff officer.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: What, Mr. Cypreſs!

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Mad Captain Clifford here!—eh he don't look well, I'll be civil, (aſide.) how d'ye do a thouſand times, my dear, dear, ſir?

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Never better, thank heaven! juſt got from our meſs; dem it, they drink ſo hard.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p:
I ſee now he's freſh and florid, find every body I meet in barbarous health, (going.) Oh, but
true, I muſt wait for an anſwer from the miſtreſs of my heart.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! who is your goddeſs? Come, don't be aſham'd to tell! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Sir, I boaſt of my love for Miſs Melcomb, as her love to me is her greateſt glory!

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Miſs Melcomb!—Can it be my Julia? (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Yes; I'm the lad of her ſoul, I've ſent in my name; now you'll ſee her ardent deſire for me to ſend in myſelf.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Miſs Melcomb's not at Brighton?

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Then that houſe is not in Brighton. (pointing to that where Harry went off.)

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: My love next door to me, and I not know it!

div.stage: Re-enter Harry, both ſeeing of him.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Well, you deliver'd my card to your miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, but the ſays the knows no ſuch perſon. (Exit.)

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Not know the glorious lad of her ſoul, (Claps Cypreſs on the back.) ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: I deſire, ſir, you'll—by my honor ſhe's the moſt—

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Hold, ſir! Miſs Melcomb is a lady for whom I have the utmoſt veneration—

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: You!

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Yes, I, and for proof I'll indulge you, and in your own way too, I'll ſend in my name. (writes.)

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Not know any ſuch gentleman. (walks about.)

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Eh! but where's Miſs Melcomb's man?

div.stage: Enter COLIN from where he went off, unperceiv'd.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Here I be, ſir.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Are you her ſervant?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Oh, yez, ſir, I bes her livery man.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: And perhaps her common councilman.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Noa, ſir, I never durſt give her council, tho' I advis'd her ſometimes.—Will you walk in, old gentleman?

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Old! raſcal!

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Come, ſir, I won't hear even Miſs Melcomb's ſervant abus'd.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: That's right, ſir, love me, love my dog.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Then carry that in your paw to your miſtreſs. (Exit Colin in the houſe from whence he came out unperceiv'd.) Now Mr. Cypreſs, I don't abſolutely boaſt I'm quite her glory! but perhaps ſhe won't deſire me to ſend in myſelf. Ironical

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Sir, my lady ſays, ſhe doesn't know any thing about the perſon that wrote upon this.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Impoſſible! by heavens ſhe is the moſt capricious!—I ſee her duplicity in this ſeeming denial to Cypreſs, Julia prefer a ſordid raſcal to me! hark'ye, you old raven! your hovering about for legacies is notorious, thro' almoſt every public place in England; you have been hooted out of the rooms at Bath, drove from the pantiles at Tunbridge, and by heaven, I'll have you beat off the Steine at Brighton.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: I beat! ha! ha! ha! well, I ſhould like to ſee that.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: So ſhould I, ſir he! he! he!

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Raſcal!

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: He! he! he! Runs off.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: I'll have this refuſal from Miſs Melcomb's own lips.—No, I'll ſee her no more; but, dem me, I'll match you Mr. Cypreſs. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Miſs MELCOMB, in full dreſs, from the houſe where Colin went in and out of unperceived.

sp.speaker: Miss M.
sp.p: Colin! fetch my paraſol.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: [turns] Oh! here is my perſidious Peggy.

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: Thoſe young gentlemen will keep flying after one ſo, I'm glad I didn't bring my niece Julia here; no chance of admirers her flimſy beauty in the way.—What Mr. Cypreſs! I proteſt I'm glad to ſee, you!

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am; you'd be glad to ſee me at Pondicherry, ſo you were at the ſame time upon a Suſſex cliff, even from thence, madam, I ſhould behold you. Love is a monſtrous telegraphe: if you had any pity, you cou'd read without ſpectacles, that ſlighted paſſion is a piteous caſe.

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: What do you talk to me, ſir, of ſpectacle caſes?

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Then, madam, I'll be round with you: you might have put on your barnacles, and anſwered my card.

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: Yours! my ſervant did bring me a card juſt now, but not from you.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Forgets even my name!

sp.speaker: Miss M.
sp.p: How provoking! here's ſome gentleman has ſent his ſervant to watch me about. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Now for the library.—My miſtreſs ſhou'd have ſet down more than one number. Going.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Didn't I give you a card for your lady?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Certainly, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: And wasn't her anſwer that ſhe didn't know the writer?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Knew nothing at all about him, ſir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cylpreſs.
sp.p: There madam! Oh ſhame! that a lady can rend a man's honeſt heart, and then deny it to his miſerable face!

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: What, ſir, do you talk to me of cards to ladies; and, ſir, I can't help your miſerable face.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: You can help, madam, my bleeding heart, that you yourſelf have given the fatal ſtab to!—But—I don't care twopence about her: I'll now ſcorn in my turn.

sp.speaker: Miſs. M.
sp.p: Sir, if I have attractions, am I to blame? I didn't make them.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Make! no, Miſs, you bought your lilies and roſes ready made; the maſter of the ceremonies at your toilet places them well enough Miſs, but if one was to ſee them in a morning, there's a caſt off, and change ſides, Miſs: Where are the lilies? on the cheeks of my Phillis! where is the roſe? on her pretty little noſe! Sings.

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: Barbarous, cruel man!

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Nay now, Miſs Melcomb, my dear Peggy!

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: Sir, though I was chriſtened Margaret, I told you I was ſince confirmed Seraphina.—Seraphina is my name!

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Will you be Seraphina Cypreſs? taking her hand.

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: Colin, go to the library and aſk for the teleſcope I choſe on my fortunate raffle yeſterday. Any meſſages, you'll find me on the Steine.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: My dear Peggy—

sp.speaker: Miſs. M.
sp.p: Sir, be aſſured Miſs Melcomb will never be Mrs. Cypreſs, Exit with COLIN,

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: There's a coquet! All art, her denial to Captain Clifford. Gone to firſt with him on the Steine. How have I loſt her? Some diſguſt! Was it when ſhe pop'd in upon me t'other day whilſt I was ſhaving? She deſired me not to mind her, and like an aſs, on I went, up to the eyes in fuds, twiſſting my features into fifty ugly ſhapes before, her. When ſhe aſked me for her favourite air, like a fool I muſt play it on the german flute, and put my mouth into ſuch an uncomely ſhape: my attitudes were graceful tho'! [Imitates.] Love is gone! Come revenge! But how?
sp.stage: Enter Boy, puts hand-bills under knockers, gives one to Cypress, and exit.
sp.p: Pſhaw! peſter me with auction bills! and— Eh, [Reads.] "Great rooms—Mr. Parrots—Give imitations—principal performers—ſawing a deal board—celebrated orator—two cats in a gutter— drawing a cork"—Oh, here's an occaſion for ample revenge on my perfidious Peggy! She has killed me, and I'll make her ridiculous! Oh, I'll have her among the cats and gutters! Exit

div.head: SCENE II.—The Steine, before Gregory's library —A view of the ſea—Company walking, converſing, &c— JULIA, and others reading,

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: [To Shopman]. I deſired my ſervant to call for the book. No matter: I'll take it myſelf.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: [Writing] Miſs Melcombe.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Eh, what Captain Clifford is this? [Looking at book.] My dear Charles at Brighton! moſt certain!

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Oh, here is Julia! Moſt obedient ma'am.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Ma'am—ſo cool! well then, your moſt obedient, ſir. Ah, I was once the lovelieſt creature in the world: waſn't I, Charles? Look in my face wretch: Is not there now ſomebody elſe more lovely?

lg.head: I.
lg.l: I'D fain aſk you a this, but in ſteps a that,
Ah! why did you, truant, away from me go?
Yet, not that I'm curious, but merely for chat,
'Tis only no harm to know it, you know.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: What lady detain'd you? I'm ſure ſhe was fair,
Much taller than I am, perhaps full as low;
No buſineſs of mine 'tis—what colour her hair?
'Tis only no harm to know it, you know.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Pray, was ſhe demure? or coquetiſhly gay?
The voice of a cherub, or may be ſo, ſo?
Her eyes—I don't aſk whether hazle or grey,
'Tis only no harm to know it, you know.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: But one thing, O, tell me! No more then impart,
Did'ſt give her what was not your own to beſtow?
Tho' ſure you'd not venture to give her your heart,
'Tis only no harm to know it, you know.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Why, ma'am, you're very pleaſant.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Certainly; this is the place for pleaſure. But how long have you been at Brighton?

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Long enough, madam, to receive proofs of what I never even ſuſpected.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Don't talk ſo loud; the people are all ſtaring at us.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Oh, madam, it's your ambition to be ſtared at, by young and old!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I was going to take a turn on the Cliff; come, give me your arm, and let's know what is this mighty buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: 'Pon my honor, ma'am, this is exceeding well—my arm! then you are not afraid of meeting old Cypreſs?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Now bleſs your pretty little ſoul, Charles, who is old Cypreſs.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Oh, ma'am, that incomprehenſibility of ſurpriſe is abſurd: you firſt refuſed to admit Cypreſe, becauſe I was in the way; then, to ſoften him by a compleat triumph over me, you ſend me out word—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I ſend you out word; of what pray?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: I want the telepope, that miſtreſs won with the dice-box.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: [Stops him.] Oh! I gave you a card for your lady: you brought out for anſwer that ſhe did'nt know me?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Yez ſir. [Exit into ſhop.]

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: But what's all this to me?

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Ma'am, you ſeem very careleſs about it; but I think it's very much to you; and Julia, all in all to me: [Tenderly.] therefore, madam, I inſiſt—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Hold, ſir! you forget yourſelf: Such behaviour in a public place?

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: But, Julia, ſure I have a right to demand an explanation.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh, my valiant Captain! To proceed in form: hadn't you beſt ſend me a challenge?—but you may take it for granted, ſir, whether in reſentment or affection, this is the laſt time I ſhall ever give you the meeting. Exit.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: I'll flog Grogan! no, the good-natured people round have witneſs'd my inſulting a woman; they ſha'n't add to my diſgrace by ſeeing me beat an old man! Oh, Julia! at our tender parting did I think to meet you thus?

lg.head: I.
lg.l: How bitter the moment, with thoſe we hold dear,
When exchanging the tender adien;
I follow'd you far with my eyes, when a tear
Hid the object I lov'd from my view.
I penſive retir'd to forget you; ah, vain!
I found ſolitude cheriſh'd deſpair;
In company ſought a relief from my pain:
Your dear image ſtill follow'd me there.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Thro'grove, mead, and garden I varied the ſcene,
With fond hope ſome repoſe I might find;
But ſtill a lov'd ſpot, where together we've been,
Some lov'd incident brought to my mind.
When I muſe in the grove, there I ſee your dear name,
That I carv'd on the rind of a tree,
In a garden I'm charm'd with a roſebud, the ſame,
Whence a flower you preſented to me.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: I range thro' the me down attended by Tray,
Once yours:—his affection is prov'd
And the linnet's ſweet pipe can bleſt raptures convey,
When he carrols the tune that you lov'd.
By moonlight I walk, I enjoy her mild rays,
And this heart ſoothing fancy purſue:
I think at the inſtant whilſt on her I gaze,
She then may be look'd on by you.

sp.p: Eh! isn't this Mr.Parrots, the celebrated Iriſh mimick? Ha! ha! ha! A capital miſtake in talent his, attempts to imitate every character and dialect the moſt oppoſite; yet, with ſuch an invincible brogue, that when he fancies he ſpeaks or ſings a variety of voices, you can only think yourſelf in a debating ſociety at Tipperary,

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Waiter, prepare me a good breakfaſt of ſome tea and cakes; but if you can't get three new laid eggs, you may eat them all yourſelf.—Captain Clifford, how do you do, ſir?

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Ha! Mr. Parrots, true I ſaw your bills for performance.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, I'm come to give my imitations, and have hir'd a fine big room; but ſuch a buſhel of troubles—

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: I'm glad you're come Parrots, I wanted ſomething to laugh at, this place is very pleaſant, eh? the Steine, —and Downs, —and bathing, —

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p:
Bathing! oh a bleſſed affair happen'd to me, the very day I arriv'd, I was ſo afraid of nobody coming to hear me, that I was about to go back to London; ſo I took my place in the
machine, but inſtead of a ſtage coach, they put me into a wooden cloſet, and dragg'd me into the ſea: Hallo! ſays I, let me out! Off with your cloaths, ſays the fellow, and tumble out here headlong.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Well, I thought I'd ſtay here a few days longer, if only to pick up, among their bathing ſhops, and raffling Machines, a new ſtock of originals; and faith. I've been at them eves dropping about every where, why t'other night in the playhouſe, I had a Scotch preſbyterian calling to the muſic for God ſave the King! A French marquis bawling for Roaſt Beef! and an Iriſhman roaring for Rule Britannia!

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Oh, you've him at your tongue's end.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Who, the Iriſhman? now there you're out: he has ſuch a devil of a brogue, that he's the only perſon there I cannot mimick neatly.

lg.l: I'M the man that can take off every fowl,
From the ſinging Lark, to the barking Dog.
[Hark! the Lark (mimicks) now the Dog.]
All beaſts I can mimick upon my foul,
From the cackling Hen, to the grunting Hog.
[Tie Hen, (mimicks) the Hog, (mimicks)
All's food for wit, that falls into my diſh,
Like crowing Cock, I'm a fine bird-call,
And yet I cannot well mimick a fiſh,
Becauſe that a fiſh ſays nothing at all.

lg.head: Burden
lg.l: At all jolly parties I make a rout,
I'm call'd for my ſong; for a joaker I paſs;
But ſome how or other—I bring it about,
That the people all think me a fine jack-Aſs,

lg.head: II.
lg.l: At Hanover Square when your Concert plays,
Like them I can Preſto, Piano too,
I ſing and I whiſtle with ſo much eaſe,
The black Crow's neat ſong, and the tight Cuckow,
The ſawing Boards, and the drawing of Cork,
And water as dropping, drop, drop, drop,
I tune up my pipe, with my great pitch-fork,
At the bottom now, and now at the top.

lg.head: BURDEN.
lg.l: At all jolly parties I make a rout,
I'm call'd for my ſong; for a joaker I paſs;
But ſome how or other I bring it about,
That the people all think me a fine Jack-Aſs.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! this offers ſomething for old Cypreſs. [Aſide.] Mr. Parrots, if you ſhou'dn't be encouraged here, equal to your merits, you may eaſily get money for your travelling expences however.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Then how? my dear ſir!

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Liſten.—A gentleman here had an old friend, whom he once inſulted groſsly: this friend hadn't ſpirit to reſent it himſeif, yet dying lately, carried his reſentment to his laſt breath, abſolutely in his will left a legacy of a hundred pounds, to any one that wou'd cane him on the open Steine. Now ſuppoſe you were to—

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Beat a gentleman! you don't catch me at that Captain.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Why beſides touching the Caſh, you chaſtiſe an impudent little raſcal.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: If I was to chaſtiſe all the impudent raſcals, I ſhou'd have five firſts for everyone of my ten fingers, thumbs and all.

sp.speaker: Cap. C.
sp.p: Intereſt is not the ſtring, I muſt touch, the Hibernian's courage, (aſide.) I don't think the legacy will ever be claim'd, tho' the money is a temptation, yet nobody hitherto has ventured to win it by ſtriking him, he's a remarkably ſtrong little fellow indeed, full of tricks with his ſtrength when he gets a bottle; twiſting pokers round his neck, battering pewter pots with his forehead, they talk here, (but I never believ'd it) that the cauſe of the eaſt cliffs falling, was his ſhoving in a drunken ſit one of the great guns off the battery: yes, yes it requires a deal of reſolution to—

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Why, ſir, d'ye think I'm afraid? upon the Steine you ſay? any particular time mention'd in the will?

sp.speaker: Cap. C.
sp.p: Eh, yonder is old Cypreſs, (aſide.) when there's a good deal of company about; now, a propos, look, that's your man.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: What that clergyman bowing to the ladies? or the man in deep mourning laughing ſo hearty? (looking out.)

sp.speaker: Cap. C.
sp.p: Pho, dem it, look there.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Oh the little ſquab lad in the bob wig and blue and ſilver coat. But, Captain, if I do win this legacy, who's to pay it me?

sp.speaker: Cap. C.
sp.p: Zounds! what name! oh, —any, (aſide.) eh, —one—one Captain Tomkins is the executor.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: But where does he live?

sp.speaker: Cap. C.
sp.p: Any body will tell you, look that's his houſe. (points.)

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Cap. C.
sp.p: Here's jack Daily, he'll be dragging me to the bottle, (going.)

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! hollo Clifford! by heavens you're a fine fellow to ſlip off ſo!

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Pho, never mind me, there's a lady that I—

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: Zounds! meet a lady with ſuch a ſober ſtupid face, Dem it come along my boy! (ſings) "for Venus ne'er looks with a ſmile ſo divine!" (drags him off.)

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: To get my bottle I muſt firſt touch the corks; he's here, a hundred pounds is a good thing; but beating him in cold blood—by my foul I'd rather get a threſhing myſelf (ſo that nobddy might know it) than ſtrike a man that has never done me any harm.—But a ſtick is neceſſary. (Exit into ſhop)

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: I'm burning for revenge on my cruel Peg, but no finding this Mr. Parrots the mimick— a deal of faſhion here this evening. (Enter COLIN from ſhop with teleſcspe.) Oh is your lady on the Steine.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: Walking in yon voine company.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: She ſhall ſee what terms I'm on with people of condition (puts up glaſs.) Sir Luke! we'll ſettle our bet at the rooms. (Calling off.) Lady Dimple I do you ride to Rottingdeane to-morrow? Our friend the Colonel promiſes a charming treat from the Dorſet band, on the level. (Calling off.)

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, miſtreſs and I will be on the level. (puts up the Teleſcope) Dick Coachman! Shall us tig a mug of Newhaven beer a: the white horſe?

sp.speaker: Cypress.
sp.p: Colin! Cou'dn't you draw your lady this way I tell her ſha'll ſee ſomething very pleaſant.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: What, ſir, you wi child and tumbling blackamoor?

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: No make her look towards me.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: I wull. (Exit.)

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Then ſhe'll learn that I'm ſomebody for all her ſcorn.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: I'll pay you for this little hag, but now take it out an airing upon trial, (ſpeaking off.)

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Let's ſee what valetudinarian friends at Buxton. (ſits and reads, PARROTS walks round, then ſits by him.)

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: I muſt get him more amongſt the company, (aſide.) ſir, hadn't you beſt take a walk?

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Take a walk!

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, and I'll take another, and yet we'll both take the ſame walk.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Who is this man? (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: I'll make him affront me, and then it will be all his own doing. (Drops the cane on CyPRESS'S, foot.) Sir you needn't kick ſhelalah about, you and he will be better acquainted bye and bye.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: I proteſt this is an odd perſon. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: I don't like ſtriking a naked man; I wiſh he had ſome weapon, (aſide.) Sir, how d'ye like this colt? becauſe, ſir, if you'd ſtep and take a ſilly out of the ſame paddock yonder, they'd breed charming.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Breed what?

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: They'd breed a quarrel!

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: I do not like this man. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: How ſhall I rouze him! (aſide.) When that paper's out of hand, ſir, I'll thank you for it; (takes it.) I'm obliged to you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: It's now out of hand indeed.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Sir I ſay that's falſe, for now it's in hand, and yet I'll read it out of hand— (reads) On Saturday died."—

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Lord, ſir, juſt let me look at the deaths!

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Takes an affront like mull'd claret, then I'll beat him without any ceremony for the meanneſs of his ſpirit! (aſide.) Look ye, ſir? as to battering pewter pots againſt men's foreheads, and making cravats of their kitchen pokers, that's all to me a meer dog's whiſtle!

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: I never attempted to throw a cannon over a cliff like others!

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Didn't you, Sir? I beg pardon, I thought you did, —Gad this is an odd fellow! ha! ha! ha! (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Harkye, ſir, I wiſh to avoid ſtrife, and ſo—if you'll only tell the executor I did it, I'll not do it at all.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Then, ſir, you, may let it alone, what the devil's all this he's talking about, I'll do, and you'll not do.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Oh but I will if you go to that, ſblood! and thunder ſir! why don't you put me into a fury as you did the dead man? but what did you do to make the dying ſoul leave you ſuch a token of affection?

sp.speaker: Cypriſs.
sp.p: Who! what! has any deceaſed friend?—

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Ay you're left the truth of a thumping legacy!

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Indeed! where am I to receive it, my dear ſir!

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Why here.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Here! when?

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Now.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Who's to pay me it?

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: I told my lady ſir, and ſhe and company are all looking.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: The executor may want a witneſs—

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Witneſs! why, my dear ſir, won't my receipt do? Come we'll get pens, ink, and ſtamp in the ſhop.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: No, leaving a mark will do for this,— you ſtand there, and obſerve what paſſes. (to Colin.)

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Tell your lady what marks of affection I receive from others. Now I'm ready to take it.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: And I to give it.— (Strikes him.)

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Murder! help!

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: There I've tried the poney— (throws it down.) Now to tell the Captain, and then for a touch at the executor! Exit,

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Oh heavens! oh my back!

sp.speaker: Collin.
sp.p: Then this is the joke they're to ſee, —he! he! he! how my lady laughs, all the gentlefolks be's laughing at you! he! he! he! he! what a happy man you be, to make people ſo merry! he! he! he!

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p:
Merry, you dem'd Villain, yes I'm very happy, publickly diſgrac'd! Miſs Melcomb may indeed now deſpiſe me, I myſelf to draw her attention and be curſt to me, I'll write to her,— Explain what I don't underſtand, I'll go—oh isn't this my old landlady! [enter Landlady,] Eh,
now, good dame, where are you gadding, and nobody at home to light me a candle?

sp.speaker: Landlady.
sp.p: Ah, Mr, Cypreſs, I wiſh I could afford to keep a maid, but lawk one muſt call in upon one's neighbours to ſee whether they're dead or alive.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: What then you're a legacy hunter? you ſelfiſh creature! I ſay return home and light my candles!

sp.speaker: Landlady.
sp.p: Ah, ſir, take a couple of turns more on the Steine, for the ſea air is ſo wholeſome for you phthyſicy old gentlemen. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: There's a ſcandalous goſſip! eh, ſhe's gone into the apothecary's ſhop, ſome hope of an old woman that goes into an apothecary's ſhop, I'll make her a preſent of a pair of fleecy hoſiery gambadoes.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Oh here's the poney. (takes up ſtick.)

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Boy, you ſtep home with me to ſtrike a light, and carry a letter to your lady.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, he! he! he! you be more comical than tumbling blackamoor.—How cleverly he managed the poney, here he went ſo! and then he went ſo! (flouriſhing it over Cypreſs's head.)

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Why you dam'd raſcal! (ſnatches it, Colin run off.) What will Peggy think of me, ſure ſhe won't have me after this public diſgrace, well if not, I'll ſtill purſue her; perhaps when ſhe dies ſhe may leave me ſomething in token of former friendſhip.

lg.l: OUR joys are all fled,
Oh! alas, and alack!
My friend now lies dead,
And the houſe hung with black.
How can his lov'd wife
Her yaſt ſorrows endure?
She's loſt to all life,
As the Mutes at the door.
Our handkerchiefs wave,
And our hearts are in dole;
He's laid in the grave,
And we think on the—cole.
With glaſs of wine we'll cheer our woe,
And wipe our muzzy faces,
Then hey! for Doctor's Commons go,
To ſee how there the caſe is.
"I have the fortune," cries one ſon,
"And t'other not a ſouſki,"
The wife ſings, "My kind huſband's gone,
"He was a rouſi-ouſki."
Executors grand!
Now think how they can crib,
Left plate, houſe and land,
To his dear loving rib.
With widow we dine,
All bachelors met,
The hatchment's the ſign,
There's a wife to be let.
So lonely her-bed!
Her ſad heart ſure will break;
She ſwears ſhe can't wed
In leſs than a—week.
With glaſs of wine, &c.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p:
And Clifford lives next door to me?—I will not live next door to him—Harry—You muſt look out other lodgings, —Then this was the cauſe of his behaviour to me!—ah! fye! fye!
men are all baſe, and venal. (aſide.) How long has your brother and his miſtreſs been here?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: But a few days, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: And Captain Clifford you ſay ſent in a tender meſſage to my aunt?—that is your brother Colin's Lady—the other Miſs Melcomb?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Moſt certainly, ma'am —I didn't know your ladyſhip had an aunt; they ſay ſhe's very rich? but that to he ſure you know.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: And that ſhe is very rich my falſe Clifford to be ſure knows, —But dear he need not be vain of his conqueſt, for my venerable aunt throws out her lure for every bird that flies! he fancies it is his fine perſon that has caught her, but I'll convince him, that with all his grace, and accompliſhments and ſweet voice, he may be ſupplanted by the firſt inſignificant, dangling coxcomb, that chuſes to pay her any attention, (aſide.) Harry you're acquainted with ſome of the officers' ſervants?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Oh yes, madam—very genteel valets.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Then if you know any very genteel valet—that has a very ſmart little maſter—whoſe regimentals would fit me—

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Madam!— (ſurpriſed.)

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Borrow them—ha, ha, ha!—I think I ſhall make a ſmart Brighton Officer! I can dance—ſport my uniform on the Steine—chatter at the libraries—ſhew the ladies my neat marquee— then at our camp and review,
sp.l: The cows and ſheep my only foes,
With pops of powder, fright the crows!

div.head: SCENE III. —Moon light. Cliff before CYPRESS'S houſe—Enter CAPTAIN CLIFFORD, Celevated with Wine, ſinging.

sp.speaker: Capt. C,
sp.p: What's company, wine, mirth, without love! women ſhould be indulged in their little caprices and pets, ſince man cannot exiſt without their charming ſmiles. I'll call on my divine Julia, throw myſelf at her feet, and aſk her pardon.
sp.stage: (A light appears at the upper window; CYPRESS ſeated in cap and gown writing.)

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Ecod I'll wait on him no longer, my lady will want me, and this old rogue will give me nothing.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Julia's ſervant! where have?—who lives here?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Mr. Cypreſs, ſir.

sp.speaker: Capt C.
sp.p: Zounds! totally forgot—I wonder if Parrots performed the exploit! Dem that 'tother bottle! loſt all the fun by it, —what you're come with a letter?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: No, ſir, I ſtay to take one, his old landlady be's not yet com'd home, ſo ſtingy won't keep a maid—ſo Mr. Cypreſs bid me watch door.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Well, I want to aſk him a queſtion.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Noa, ſir, he bid me not let any one diſturb him whilſt he's writing love—

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Is that he up there?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Yes; Sir, he ſleep's in a Garret for the good air over the hills.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Go home, your lady wants you.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Does ſhe? good bye, ſir. (ſhuts door.)

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Why the devil did you ſhut the door?

sp.speaker: Colin,
sp.p: That nobody might go in, till old woman comes back.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Dem the old woman!

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: How fine theſe officers talk, dem the old woman! Exit.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Julia's diſſimulation, carrying on a correſpondence—Cypreſs has the name of money, can ſhe be ſo baſe! you're compoſing your loveletter? then I'll diſcompoſe.— (looking up, knocks at the door.)—I don't think he can know me. [Deranging his dreſs.]

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: (within) Colin! why don't you go to the door?

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: I'll teaze, but dem it what ſhall I ſay! (Cypreſs opens door with candle.)

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Where is this clown run to?

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, does Captain Tomkins liye here?

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Aſk pardon, ſir, any where in this neighbourhood, ſir?

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: 'Pon my word, ſir, I'm but a ſtranger myſelf.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Good night; ſir, —ſorry—give you— much trouble.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Oh, ſir, no trouble, good night, ſir. (ſhuts door.)

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Ay, trot up, (liſtens) ſeated? (looks up) yes— (Cypreſs appears at window, takes up pen, Captain Clifford knocks; Cypreſs ſtarts, takes candle and retires.)—ay, now trot down again. I hope he won't let his candle fall, for I like to contemplate his delectable phiz— (liſt'ning, Cypreſs opens door.)—Pray, ſir, does Captain Tomkins live here?

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: No, ſir, Captain Tomkins does not live here, eh! why, ſir, you are the gentleman aſked this inſtant!

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Bleſs my ſoul! the ſame door indeed! ſir, I aſk pardon.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Oh, ſir, no offence, —plague what keeps the old woman!

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Sir I wiſh you good night.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Oh, ſir, good night to you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: (liſt'ning.) Up we trot again, —ſet to our love-letter? Eh, I believe he has taken his pen and ink-horn into ſome other room, —oh no! there ſits old amorous Ovid, — (Knocks, Cypreſs ſtarts, appears vext, tries to open window but can't, Captain knocks.)—Oh we trot down a little faſter. (liſt'ning) demme I believe he's tumbled down— (Cypreſs opens the door.)—Pray, ſir, does Captain Tomkins live here?

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Why what the devil, ſir, I told you twice no Captain Tomkins lived here.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: I beg pardon, ſir, ſorry to give ſo much trouble.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Sir, really I don't underſtand what you mean—

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Sir your moſt obedient, I wiſh you good night.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Well, ſir, good night.— (as he's ſhutting the door, Captain Clifford puſhes it.)

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Oh, ſir, you ſeem to have loſt one of your ſlippers.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Curſe it all!

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, don't ſtay out in the cold,— you'll have a ſore throat.— (Cypreſs ſutting the door, Captain Clifford puſhes it.)—Oh but, ſir, can you tell me where Captain Tomkins lives?

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Damn it! Inquire at the publick houſes.
sp.stage: ſhutting the door Capt. Clifford puſhes it open.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, which is the publick houſe?

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Hell and ſury, I don't know!

sp.speaker: Capt. C
sp.p: Sir, I aſk pardan,— moſt obedient, good night, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: This old devil to take the key of my parlour, but I'll quit her lodgings to morrow! damn me! I'll come down no more if the houſe is on fire!
sp.stage: ſhuts the door, Enter a Porter.

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: Letter ſays number twelve.— (holds it to the lamp. Cypreſs appears at the window writing; Porter knocks, Cypreſs after many attempts, burſts open windows and looks cut.)

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: I'll come down no more! Get away you raſcal!

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: I've a letter for Mr. Cypreſs.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: A letter, oh.

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: Get away you raſcal!—don't care, the lady ſhall pay me for bringing it.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Unlucky, Captain Clifford and his jolly party broke up, but where does the executor live? the captain pointed this way, ſo ſince I'm on the ſpot, I may as well try to find it out to night, that I may be ſure of knowing it in the morning, oh this is it.— (going to knock, Cypreſs opens the doer.) Pray, ſir, does Captain Tomkins live here?

div.stage: Enter Landlady with a lanthorn going towards door Cypreſs claps it violently, ſhe fails, Parrots, runs off.—Curtain drops haſtily.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: I'll got leave of abſence, quit Brighton, and ſee Julia no more.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Ah, ſir, what did you run ſuch a hum upon me? firſt make me beat a man, then aſk himſelf for the reward?

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Mean! why Captain Tomkins is the gentleman I threſ'd, and not the executor! laft night I knock'd at the houſe, and I thought he'a have knock'd the door and myſelf into the window the other ſide the way.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Why zounds Parrots did you inquire? ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Pho, none of your laughing, ſir, tell me where the executor lives that I may get in the money, and out of the town, as he may be for bringing me before a juſtice.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! and he opened the door in a red night-cap? ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Yes he did, but never mind his red night-cap now.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: With a candle in his hand? ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Oh the devil burn your candle, ſir, what a laughing you keep!

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: And you aſked, "pray, ſir, does Captain Tomkins live here?" ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Cap. C.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! let's ſee, the captain is one executor, but you certainly went to the wrong houſe.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Well right or wrong, I'll go no more to Captain Tomkins, if there are two executors who is the other?

sp.speaker: Cap. C.
sp.p: It's Mr—Come with me, and I'll ſhew you, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Oh, ſir, if you keep grinning I won't go with you! 'pon my honor.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Now I'm ſerious, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Pay two guineas a week here and an old beldam keep no maid! Oblige me to open doors, and get myſelf inſulted by all the raff in the ſtreer. I'll directly for town—pack up my cloaths—

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, it's all along of you!

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Colin! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p:
You wou'd bring me away laſt night todling
after you, and while I was out miſtreſs was in a worry to ſend me with a letter.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Ay to Captain Clifford I warrant, I'm glad I didn't ſend my letter to her.—well?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: And ſo when I com'd hoame, Colin, ſays ſhe, you're an honeſt creature and the beſt zarvant that ever flouriſed a flambeau, but I diſcharge you for an idle vagabond. I've loſt my place on your account, and if you've any conſcience you'll get me another or take me yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: This fellow will tell me all her ſecrets. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: I'm now an honeſt mon out of bread, bread bes the ſtaff of life, and without it I ſhall tumble down, as you wou'd was I to trip you up. (puſhes him.)

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Damn your illuſtrations you dog!—but his coming is a propos, to prepare and attend me on my journey—I fear you're a ſad fellow—

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, I bes ſad out of pleace, hire me, and I'll be a merry fellow.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: But living with a lady has ſpoil'd you.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: But I have liv'd with a gentelman who was ſometimes a prince! ſometimes a Roman duke!

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Did he keep a coach?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: No, ſir, he was an Italian, ſo the Engliſh nobility kept a coach for him, ſir. My maſter ſung in the Haymarket, he told me, ſir, he uſed to ſing for the Pope; ecod, he was a comical fellow, they call'd him the firſt Buffalo.

div.head: AIR.—COLIN.
div.l: In his ring he wore a ſinger,
Much be lov'd to munch Bologni!
Caro then his month he'd open,
In the coffee houſe Spring Garden,
At the Orange take his coffee,
At the bar whips op a jelli,
Nice ſallad, if he ſhou'd eye any,
With peenyo he will buy any.
Cuto with the knife or forko
Jaw to worko, draw ſe corko.
Horſe in carto there he metti,
Hair-bag full was ſtuffed with hay,
He ſteps in ſtep up I puto,
On his fingers, door I ſhuto,
Dere he laugh at Johnny Bull,

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Well, I'll try you—ſtep to the caſtle Inn, deſire them to ſend me a poſt chaiſe about eleven; tell the maſter I'd join for part, if he knows any infirm old lady or gentleman, becauſe on a journey I'm very tender of the ſick.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: So am I, ſir, 'twou'd do your heart good to get ſick only to ſee how careful I'd nurſe you— law, I had it of feyher and mother; an old friend, (that they didn't care two—pence about, only hoped he'd leave them ſomething when he kicked,) was woundy ill in our ſtreet; mother uſed to make him nice barley-broths—and wi little puddings;—ecod, ſhe once ſent him a roaſt chicken, and would you think it, after all, he ſlip'd up to heaven without leaving them a marvadee!

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: That was a bilk! to heaven! no, he ſlip'd down to t'other place, for his damn'd ingratitude!

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Then, ſir, when you are ſick, I'll take ſuch care of you, that the ſooner you go up to heaven, ard leave me ſomething—the better for us both; 'twill be ſo unexpected you know, (going.)

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Hem?mdash;where are you going?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: To bid them have chay at twelve.

sp.speaker: Cpreſs.
sp.p: There, wrong already, I ſaid eleven; when I give you a meſſage always repeat my words exactly.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: I woll; but, ſir, old landlady's gone out again, and a lady inquir'd for you as I com'd in.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Oh, 'tis lady Squab; true, I promiſed to ride with her to Rottingdeane—plague on't I've no humour for parties of pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: She be ſitting in parlour great chair.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Weil, there let her ſit, and when ſhe's tired ſhe may walk off. (peevish.)

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: (Bawling) Lady Squab! ſit in big chair, and when you're tired, walk off!

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: S'death and fury!

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Wasn't that ſpeaking your words exactly?

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Never bawl out ſo! (knocking without.) That's Tom Nibble, don't ſay I'm at home.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: I won't. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: My brains boiling from Seraphina's falſehood, and teaz'd by a parcel of people galloping in upon me, all in impudent rude health too, no ſpeculation of advantage from their death.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: (Softly.) Sir, I told Mr. Nibble; he bes in the next room, writing a card to leave.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: What do you ſay? I hate whiſpering.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Zur! I told the gentleman you wan't at home, as you deſired me. (very loud.)

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: The devil's in the fellow's bawling!

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Why, law, ſir, a poor ſervant don't know when to tell lies and when to tell truth.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Tell lies to all the world, but truth to your maſter. Colin, I think your miſtreſs will repent loſing me; ſhe fancies her Captain Clifford a very charming object in his blue ſleev'd waiſtcoat, and his braſs cap and feathers, and ſword—when I'm dreſs'd! eh, Colin?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, you've the advantage of the captain, he looks handſome in his regimentals, but you're ugly always.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: What, ſirrah?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Tell truth to my maſter! beſides, ſir, every body that ſaw you threſh'd on the Steine, ſays you're ſuch a deſperate coward.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p:
What! I muſt retrieve my character, (takes ink and paper,) right; I'll ſend that Iriſh fellow a challenge; bring me a light. (Cypreſs writes, exit Colin.) I don't know who the ſcoundrel is, or Where he is to be found, but Colin will ſpread the
report through Brighton that I did challenge him, which will anſwer the ſame purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Ugly always!

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: How dare you ſay, and even repeat ſuch a thing to me?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Tell truth to my maſter.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Truth, hem! yes, my lad; but diſcretion bids us not to be over ready with our tongues; think three times before you ſpeak once, (writes with his head near the candle.) You muſt find out that gentleman that affronted me yeſterday on the Steine, and bear him this my mortal challenge.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Yez, ſir, —I think once, I think twice, I think three times, —your wig's on fire! (it blazes.)

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Get away from me you raſcal! [beats him] I take ſuch a fellow?—burn my wig!—my challenge all blotted too!

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Don't trouble yourſelf, ſir; here comes the very gentleman, ſo you may deliver it yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: I will. [tears it] oh, lord! I'm going to London; help me with my luggage, ſirrah. [Pulls trunks about, throws clothes over him.]

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Well, as the captain has ſent me now to the right executor, he has made amends for all his capers.—Oh! lucky, ſtop boy, as you ſaw me trim the old man yeſterday you muſt ſtay, and be my voucher that I did it; there's, half-a-crown for your gentility—oh, the gentleman, I preſume; good morning to you, ſir; according to the will, I beat the old man yeſterday, and if you don't believe it, here's a witneſs.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Eh! [turns, Parrots ſurprized.]

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Oh! ſir, he'll believe it without my oath.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Boy, return me that half-crown.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: If you're come to renew your barbariſm, I'll bawl murder out of the window, you villain.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: I'm had again!—I might expect this, when the captain got upon his red night caps—I find now he has brought me to the ſame houſe, only it looks into another ſtreet.—

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Begone!

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Sir, are you Mr. Cypreſs, or Captain Tomkins, or the executor, or the dead man, or the legatee, adminiſtrator, or teſtator? In the devil's name, who are you? I have earn'd the legacy, and will have it.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs,
sp.p: What legacy?

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: The hundred pound!

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Are you dreaming? Who told you of this hundred pound?

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Why, faith, a queer kind of genius enough ſet me on, —but, do you know one Capt. Clifford?

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Capt. Clifford! I ſee it, a concerted plan between him and Miſs Melcomb. (aſide.) You've been impoſed on.

sp.speaker: Parrots,
sp.p: Why, I ſuſpect there has been ſome hum; but no harm done; I wiſh you good morning.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Sir, there has been a deal of harm, and I'll have juſtice.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Be eaſy, you look like a kind hearted gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Zounds! who are you?

sp.speaker: Parrots
sp.p:
Sir, I'm a gentleman without an eſtate, tho' I'm an elder brother, as my father had no ſon
but myſelf, ſo I'm oblig'd to live upon ſecondhand voices; ſince there's no legacy, I muſt exhibit my imitations in the big room, [aſide.] Sir, my bill, I hope you'll honour it. [gives bill.]

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: The devil, are you Mr. Parrot's, the Mimic? Very lucky you are, for I intended to have kill'd you.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: I'faith that wou'd have been a new thing to me.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: The very man I wiſh'd to ſee.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: I thought ſo, ſir, therefore introduced myſelf to you.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: What, with your oak ſapling, you wicked fellow? however, I forgive all; I'll ſtart you a character to mimic, the moſt whimſical lady!

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: But is ſhe well known?—a great bird?

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Who? Miſs Melcomb! the feather of the faſhion.—Oh! ſhe once lov'd me.

sp.speaker: tarrets.
sp.p: And ſhe doesn't now? well, ſecond thoughts are beſt.My dear ſir introduce me to her.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: She won't let me introduce myſelf.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: But I muſt hear her actions, and ſee her talk, or how die devil can I mimic her?

sp.speaker: Landlady,
sp.p: [with out.] Yes, ſir, very airy.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: This curſed old woman, dancing the people in upon me to ſee die lodgings.

sp.speaker: Landlady.
sp.p: Ay, ſir, you'll not find more pleaſant lodgings in the town.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p:
Oh; ſomebody here [ſtruts about] dem it, madam, band-boxes! not room to whip a cat— [opens windows, flings chairs about, throws himſelf en ſofa] don't let me diſturb any body.—Eh! ſure the
old blade that ſent the card to my lady this morning.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Peggy's other ſervant! (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: A very ſaucy conceited gentleman this.;

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: No object in the proſpect. (Looking out of the window, Parrots ſnatches hat and flings it out of window.)

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Now, ſir, you've a capital object, how d'ye like it.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Dem me, ſir!—well, ma'am, if I don't ſee any thing more to my fancy, I ſhall call again.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: His miſtreſs ſend him to look for lodgings in this houſe! then ſhe can't know I live here. [aſide.] That was Miſs Melcomb's ſervant, run after him, he'll put you in the way of ſeeing his lady, who, if you can by your mimicking make a ridiculous laughing ſtock—

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: But you muſt bring me a great deal of company, —fill my rooms, with an overflow.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Yes, yes—and forgive you all.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Thanky', ſir, but if I offend a man, till I make him reparation I can't forgive myſelf, therefore I muſt aſk your pardon in;reſence of all the people that ſaw me wrong you.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: What repeated! I deſire it may end here.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: I'll make ample atonement, for I'll ſay, ſir, I'm ſorry I ſtigmatiz'd you by beating your fine old back about, with my dirty little bit of a ſtick.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Zounds! this will be more diſgrace than the thing itſelf.

sp.speaker: Parrots,
sp.p: The Steine is now full, come, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cyprſs.
sp.p: What the devil, ſir! I'll not go!

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Do you think I've nothing to do but to threſh you, then deny me an occaſion to rub off as I go? Come,—

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Damnation, ſir! I do forgive you.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: What here in a cloſet? Your nan acceptance of my conception; is a demand of ſatisfaction, that's my inference.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Confound your infernal inference and impudence.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Only walk with me up the Steine, before the pavilion, on the parade—and I will, in the hearing of them all—

sp.speaker: Cypreſs,
sp.p: Get out of my houſe.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Have a care, or before I clear off one flogging, you'll make me give you another why, I believe I muſt keep a tally to ſcore down all the apologies I have to make you.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Well, ir, I attend you.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: No, ſir, I'll wait oh you.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Curſe your poſiteneſs. Exeunt,

div.head: SCENE III.—Pavilion, Parade.
div.p: Company converſing, walking, &c. Carriages, borſes, croud, tents, ſentinels, &c. Military band; first, wind inſtruments, plaintive Scotch air; then drums and fifes—quick Irish tune.

sp.speaker: Julia,
sp.p: I think I've paſt, hitherto, quite, officer-like:—now for'a loving attack upon my aunt Margaret.— From, the time ſhe came out, ſhe ſhould be here by this.

lg.l: My bluſhes I muſt with my ſex now forget,
Tho' coy I'm no longer a maid,
In bright burniſh'd Gorget a brazen face ſet,
A ball room ſhall be my parade,
In nice chicken gloves as I gallantly ſtand,
While ſiddles for action prepare,
For dear pas-de-deux, give the word of command
And gracefully foot to the fair,
With ha! ha! ha! Fal-tal-ta! Sa, ſa, ſa

lg.head: II.
lg.l: At meſs when old care in a bumper is drowned,
Let the toaſt give a zeſt to each glaſs,
When Bacchus the temples of Cupid has crowned,
I reel off to my favourite laſs,
"Moſt lovely," ſays I, "O thou witty and fair,
Permit me to play with your fan,"
I'll ſtrut and I'll ſmile, dem it quite militaire!
'Pon my ſoul I'm a very fine man!
With ha-ha-ha, &c.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: When I thought he was coming out of the ſtreet door with me, to run back and lock himſelf up in his garret! Captain Clifford told me he Was as ſtrong as a camel! Oh, here's Miſs Melcomb's ſaucy footman.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: Madam!—Well, ma'am, I've ſeen variety of lodgings.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Huſh! how indiſcreet. apart.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p:
Madam!—I'm ſure he did ſay madam. Oh, oh! then this muſt be the lady Cypreſs deſired me to mimick, Such a beautiful creature love
him! may be ſo, as the F's fat, fair, and forty was all the toaſt of the young men.—Who knows but the S's ſhriveled, fallow, and ſixty may be the rage of the young women. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: If Clifford quits Brighton, and carries my aunt off with him, I ſhall have no occaſion to change.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: This Iriſh muſic is very fine.—Pray, ſir, how do you like Planxty Connor?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I don't know any ſuch perſon.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Perſon! why, ſir, its—'Pon my ſoul ſhe is a pretty little fellow!—Dreſt herſelf up for ſome frolick I ſuppoſe.—When a lady is inclin'd for fun, a gentleman ſhould take half the buſineſs on himſelf. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I muſt brazen it out. (Aſide.) Sir, you ſpoke to me.—Any buſineſis?

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Why, ſir, I have no objection, ſir.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Over a bottle?

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Ay, ſir, any way, ſir! that's a pretty cap upon your head; isn't it heavy? doesn't it hurt your forehead?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: This. (Takes off the belmet.) Oh, no; I'm uſed to wearing a cap.

sp.speaker: Parrots,
sp.p: Hem! I believe you are indeed. (Aſide.) that's a fine big ſword: who tied you to it?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: What, ſir!(fiercely.) ſir, my ſword is tied to me.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: It it, ſir?—Oh, ſhe is a lovely little ſoul; but can ſhe think of ſuch an old crab as Cypreſs! however, as he'll pay me for mimicking her, I'll do it;—and now to catch her manner. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: My captain! I dare ſay to meet my aunt, for yonder ſhe trips:—I muſt keep up my character though. (Aſide.) But, ſir, the aforeſaid bottle.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Ay, ſir, I'm for a bottle and its concomitants.

lg.l: Give Jove divine! a merry companion to me,
Then with g jod wine a very boon couple are we.
Leave no ſpace in your jolly full glaſs:
In your empty glaſs leave no wine:
By drinking deep this, and high filling that!
We make our noſes ſhine.
Give Love divine! my favourite girl to me;
Then with good wine, a very fond couple are we.
But if ſhe think of another whilſt I
To her my ſoul reſign,
A roſy bumper my heart ſhall cheer!
And make our noſes ſhine.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Julia take lodgings in the very houſe with Cypreſs!

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Oh, Captain, are not you aſhamed of yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Parrots! what are you at here?

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: My buſineſs!—I.'m come to mimic Miſs Melcomb.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: What!—unkind as ſhe is, I can't ſuffer this. (Aſide.) Harkye, Mr. Parrots, we ſhall quarrel if you turn your talents of mimickrv to any freedom with that lady.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: You have turned your talents of hum to a great deal of freedom with me.—I've play'd enough; I muſt now work a little.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh, here is my aunt Margaret. (Aſide. Puts up glaſss,) A deviliſh fine woman, 'pon my ſoul

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: "Deviliſh fine woman, 'pon my ſoul."

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: What little martinet have we here?"

sp.speaker: parrots.
sp.p: "What little martinet have we here?"

sp.speaker: Serjeant.
sp.p: (Without.) To the right about!

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: "To the right about!" (Mimicks.) Zounds, ſir! you've confuſed me ſo, I don't know whoſe voice I'm catching at; if it's the lady's, or the ſerjeant's, or yourſelf, or myſelf.

div.stage: Enter MISS MELCOMB, in riding habit—JULIA bows to her, kiſſes her hand ſighs paſſionately, and exit.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Parrots, who is that puppy?

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Oh, he's a very great admirer of one Miſs Melcomb.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Indeed! (Exit haſtily.)

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: M. A very impudent young man!

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Oh, you are gready affronted.

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: I think 1 look better liſtening to the muſic on horſeback, beating time with my little whip. Eh, isn't that my lord? Title is charming! the privilege of dreſſing as one pleaſes, (no matter how) it's ſoon follow'd becauſe worn by 'the Ducheſs! talk loud in the libraries! politics, a bold manly voice, ſtagger about, have a finical dangling church beau ſnuffling and flammering, "Yes, maddam, juſt the opinion of Monteſquieu, your grace." Then I look round, to ſee the ſmall gentry's embaraſſment—As I canter by their parlour windows, make a full ſtop, up with my glaſs, then hey, gallop off, turn full front like a gallant officer!

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p:
Faith I thiink ſhe throws a bit of an ogle upon me—I'll give her a little touch of one of
my die aways—hiegho! (ſighs, kiſſes his handkerchief and gazes at her.)

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: That gentleman ſeems to admire, what timid baſhfulneſs, —only ſteals a glance.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: One may gueſs what's the matter with this dowager, how ſhe's bridling, and purring about, like an old tabby cat.

sp.speaker: Miſs. M.
sp.p: Seems deeply ſmitten.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: The devil (ſhe'll ſtretch her neck off her head! heavens! how ſhe rolls her twinklers, now ſhe ſhuts them, there's a ſmile looping the corners of her mouth to the guſſet of her eyes. Faith I believe it's for me; we are making ſwans and peacocks of ourſelves; this may be a ſhorter cut to the caſh than my imitations, I'll ſay ſomething comical and witty to her— (aſide.) Pray, ma'am, what's a'clock?

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: Sir, I'm paſt two.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Yes, madam, you are paſt two—and, forty (aſide.) Lord, madam, how fond you young ladies are of walking up and down.

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: I wiſh I hadn't been ſo haſty in diſcharging that ſimple fool Colin, I already feel the inconvenience of being without a ſervant.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Speak your commands, madam; ſhall I order your carriage? is that it! with ſhoulder knotſ on the horſes heads?

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: No, ſir, but it's an handſome equipage.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: That's the reaſon, madam, I thought it was yours, for when one is handſome themſelves it gives a beauty to every thing that belongs to them. I'm ambitious madam to be your's, for at preſent I'm but an ordinary fellow.

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: Be mine, ſir.! what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Faith, I believe I was too quick to the point there. (aſide.) Madam, I meant—no meaning at all. (bows.)

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: A very polite man indeed. (aſide.) Oh, ſir, when a tender idea comes in the ſhape of a compliment, 'tis an over-delicate modeſty to be aſham'd of revealing it.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Yes, madam, modeſty is the fault of all my countrymen. Mine had like to have been the death of me; laſt week a great muſician, no faith he was a phyſician, ordered me—ſaying, "Mr. Parrots you ſhou'd go into the hot-bath." So I went ma'am, and I ſaw two doors cloſe together, by my ſoul I was ſo modeſt that I didn't aſk the man which was which, ſo opening one, inſtead of the hot, I plung'd over head and ears into the cold bath. Oh, the ſhock was ſuch a devil of a ſurprize!

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha? I proteſt, ſir, juſt ſuch an error was made—

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Wirh who pray, ma'am?

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: My lap-dog little Bluff! but I ſent the dear creature to the cold, and the man ſlung him into the hot bath.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: The ſame miſtake as mine, only 'twas quite the reverſe; what was the matter with the pretty little ſoul?

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: What ſoul, ſir?

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Your lap dog, madam!

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: Oh the dear little animal, quite in the gaitedu coeur, was friſking about to amuſe me, jumping up to catch flies, unfortunately ſwallowed one.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Swallow a live fly, ma'am! You ſhoul'd have made him ſwallow a ſpider to deſtroy it.

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: And pray, ſir, what ſhou'd I have ſent after the ſpider?

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p:
There, madam, ends my ſkill as a glaſs
blower; however I'll illuſtrate it by example, ſuppoſe a poor debtor was flying from his country in a ſhip—my caſe, (aſide,) the ſhip is caſt away, and the debtor's ſwallowed by a whale, —not my caſe— (aſide,) then I'd ſend an attorney after him.

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: Very pleaſant, —but then what wou'd you ſend after him?

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Belzebub himſelf! oh I warrant the devil would bring up the attorney, as ſure as a pair of nutcrackers!

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: No pleaſing that beggarly four crab, I wiſh my lady wou'd forgive me; oh here ſhe is, and that Iriſh buck ſmirking at her: now or never's my time to catch her in a good humour, (aſide.) do, my lady, pray take me again into your ſervice; kind ſir! put in a good word for me.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: I will; madam, if the poor devil has had the misfortune to offend you, I'll anſwer he'll never repeat it, and the next time he does, caſhier him, without bail or main-prize.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: If Mr. Cypreſs gets me to neglect you again, this gentleman, my friend, here, ſhall lay two ponies on his back, like a pair of drumſticks.

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: Well, mind your buſineſs in future.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am (joyful.) porter brought back letter laſt night from Mr. Cypreſs, 'tis on your toilet, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Miſs. M.
sp.p: Don't talk to me of Mr. Cypreſs.—I can't bear thoſe ſtaring officers!—Colin, prepare the horſes, I'll ride towards the camp.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: One way to avoid the officers. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: No, it's like to rain—I'll take an airing in the ſociable.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Ma'am t'other day I and a friend went out in my ſociable, and we convers'd very jocoſe, at laſt we quarrelled about ſpelling of a finger poſt, and my friend pull'd my noſe in my ſociable, and I with one bother knock'd my friend out of his ſociable.—Madam, will you ſtep over to Mr. Jones's ſhop to hear him play on his Welth harp?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Permit me the honour, mem—mem, your hand. aſide.

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: The pretty little officer! oh ſy, ſir, d'ye think l'd admit ſuch liberties, ſir? I don't know what you mean, ſir! I'd have you to know, ſir! I'm not the perſon, ſir!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh mem—dear mem— pon my ſoul, mem—that is—ſir, your moſt: obedient (triumphantly to PARROTS. Exit galanting Miſs MELCOMB.)

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Well this is fine, after all my modeſty and politeneſs ſhe has walk'd off with the impudent little officer—hollo Dowager you're miſtaken in your man, I've heard of ſuch marriages; oh muſtn't let the fine old lady be deceiv'd; eh, iſn't that my friend the Rev. Dick Bellange, oh, oh! I'll talk to him. Exit.

div.head: SCENE IV.— The ſtreet before Miſs MELCOMBS' bouſes.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Stop, my lad!—but why ſhould I teaze myſelf, —what concern to me now where Julia goes!—yet to take lodgings in the very houſe with Cypreſs!—by heavens!—I will talk to her about it.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Sir, I did ſtop, what bes I to do now?

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Where are you going?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: I bes not going, —I ſtand ſtill!

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Is your lady at home?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Noa, in the muſic ſhop, with a beautiful little officer.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Turned off old Cypreſs, and now got a beautiful little officer? (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Good bye, ſir, 'tis as much as my pleace be worth, —not to moin'd my buſineſs now,—

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Eh, but isn't it there your lady lives? the houſe next door to me?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: I knows nought of what houſe wives next door to you, but Miſs Melcomb, my miſtreſs bides here.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Well I thought Julia liv'd—but no matter; I'll ſtop till ſhe comes in. runs in.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: He ſays he'll ſtop, and then he jumps up ſtairs, and when I ſtop, he cries, "where be you going?" I'll be hanged if this young chap, be's not in love; ah when a mon's in love, he does'nt know which he ſhould put, his hat, or his pumps, on his head, or his heels.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: My brother!—Ah Colin! how d'ye do? how d'ye do? (foppiſhly)

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: How yee do' how yee do? (aping)

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: 'Pon my ſoul, my dear fellow, I languiſh'd for this rencontie' to interrogate you about this family, —you ſay you live with—

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: I bes as curious to know about the family you lives with.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Well, but we havn't time to talk over our own affairs now.—Pray did you ſee an Officer go in there? (points.)

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: What Captain Clifford? he be's juſt bruſhed into our houſe.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Oh! then you and your Miſs Melcombe live here? I and my Miſs Melcombe live here, next door to the Captain. I'm charged with an embaſſy to him from my lady. (going)

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Hold, — (interpoſing)—ſince my pleace is ſo uncertain, whilſt I'm in I ſhould make the moſt by perquiſites.— (aſide.)—Your embaſſy is certainly about love, and when a gentleman receives a kind meſſage from a lady, he always well rewards the perſon that brings it, —ſo I'll be dom'd brother Harry, if you ſet noſe over threſhold, till you promiſe to give me half of whatever you get.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Ha I ha! well I will. (goes in.)

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Oh, boy!

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Meaſter Cypreſs! As I have got my pleace, I don't valy him an auld gooſeberry.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: I may take a wrangling leave of Peggy however.—Did you beſpeak the chaiſe as I ordered you?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: You order me! auld boſky Joe!

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: What d'ye mean, ſirrah?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: I mean that there bes a deal of dirt in my livery coat, ſo I wiſh you'd put it on your kettle back, till I and my friend drum it out, old punmplenoſe!

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: You ſcoundrel, an't you my ſervant?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, I bes your moſt humble ſervant. bows and goes in.

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Ho! ho! (exit after.)

div.head: SCENE V. MISS MELCOMB'S dreſſing room.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Oh Miſs Melcomb's dreſſing room!— I'm impatient, yet dread to ſee her.— (looking at his watch.)—I don't like quarrels—life, where we eſteem, ſhould be a ſummer's day of ſweet complacency. Eh! Julia's toilet ſeems odly furniſh'd! phials, and ſtuffs of lotion! Paregoric Elixir! lozenges, eh, books, prophecies! Buchan! novels, "female ſtability!"—Oh from this ſhe has ſtudied her new attachment for Cypreſs, the devil, ſhe does'nt paint? A wig! why ſhe ſeems chang'd in ſoul, mind, and perſon!—Yet her face to day retain'd all its native lovelineſs! Oh, here's her other ſervant.—Shall I queſtion him?—No, that's mean.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Sir, my lady has ſent me—

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Oh then ſhe is not come home from the muſic ſhop?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Sir, ſhe's gone to take an airing towards Preſton; but ſends her compliments, and begs you'll not quit Brighton without ſeeing her.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Still think of me!—I may wrong her.— (aſide.)—Very well, for your agreeable meſſage, here— offering money

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Dam that old codger to ſtop me! come in time though, —you're right ſir, brother Harry, deſerves a guinea.—Mind, I'm to have half.—I've ten ſhillings change, ready money.— (apart.)

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Oh, oh, —ſir, pardon me, but, if you think my meſſage deſerves a reward, pray let it be about a dozen—

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Twelve?—Deuce of your impudence?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Smart, pretty, round, hard—kicks.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: What's here—a letter for Cypreſs, treacherous Julia! (a loud knocking without.)

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: My lady!

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Julia! A man's voice!—hum, —not a word of my being here, and I'll fairly divide the kicks and blows. (runs in.)

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Yes, mem, the harp is delectable, but you have a fine voice, mem.

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: Oh, ſir, you have a fine taſte.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am, and I've now and then the Voice of a humming bird, —ſinging convivial ſongs at our meſs, —has rather impaired—then we officers are obliged to give the word of command full and bold. gives the word of Command.

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: Oh, ſir, you military gentlemen are ſo terribly charming!

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: No, madam, it is I that am terrible, becauſe you are charming.—I tell you what, ſir, I thought you were harmleſs, but now I'm afraid of you, ſo quit this lady, except you can parry a bullet.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh, ſir, you ſhall ſee that— exit haſtily.

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: Heaven's! I'm all terror! Sir, declare, what brought you on the Steine this morning?

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: To take off the lovely Miſs Melcomb.

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: Indeed! but not without my conſent?

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: I didn't know that was neceſſary when Mr. Cypreſs bid me —

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: He! then he wants to recede—an anſwer to my letter laſt night,— (takes it)—heaven's! tis my own ſent back unopened. Yet it will break his heart if I give my hand to another— (aſide)—he! he! he! then, ſir, you are determined to take me off?

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: You, madam! why, this fine Maccau thinks I mean to mimick her too! Yet, how ſmiling ſhe looks.— (aſide.) Then, madam, to watch and catch you.— (mimicks)—Oh, charming lady! I have you! my manner of taking you off, muſt give univerfal pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: But, ſir, conſider—don't let the ardour of your paſſion—

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: The ardour of my paſſion!

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: The attempt to run away with me would be ſo exceedingly romantic.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Then I'm to run away with her too! Oh, very well.—Tho' we had two meanings, we're both of one mind.— (aſide.)—My lovely ſoul!—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Now, ſir, the ſurvivor take the lady.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Then I will take you my brave little lady.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Heaven's! diſcovered! (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Come to me, yourſelf, big ſword and piſtols.— (embraces her.)

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: Oh, this great man, will kill my pretty little officer!

sp.speaker: Cap. C.
sp.p: Beyond all doubt, have I caught you.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Hem!—"Pray, ſir, does one Captain Tomkins live here?"—

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: Heavens!—

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Peace!—I'll have you, my brave charmer! (embraces Miſs Melcomb.)

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: What the devil are you about with my Peggy?

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: Oh, mercy! here are four gentlemen will fight—and perhaps all be kill'd for me—oh, what miſchief in our ſaſcinating ſex!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: So, captain Clifford, you've ſet your heart on this lady?

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: ſir! I know nothing about that lady.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Really! and was it not to addreſs her that you quitted me—oh, lord! (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: You!

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: Why, certainly it is—

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: My Julia!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! then ſince I have inadvertently diſcovered myſelf—my dear aunt, how glad I am to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: My niece in this ſcandalous metamorphoſes! go, you are a ſhame to your ſex;.

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Faith, ſuch a pretty little fellow wou'd do honour to a hundred of our ſexes—How do you do, major?

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha? come Julia, you muſt forgive me ha! ha! ha! I ſee now our odd miſtakes proceeded from—ha! ha!ha! I never once thought of your aunt!

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Nor did I know the aunt had a neice.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Mr. Parrots, the parſon bes waiting up ſtairs to do the job you beſpoke him for.

sp.speaker: Miſs M.
sp.p: What, ſir! have you brought a parſon into my houſe too?

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Madam, he foretold he ſhou'd marry me to you; and the devil take him that makes a falſe prophet of a everend divine!

sp.speaker: Cypreſs.
sp.p: Fire and fury! a fine blunder you've made with your ſtupid mimickries—Peggy, ſure you won't—

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Be quiet, or I'll aſk your pardon before the whole bleſſed bevy here. (aſide.) Don't wait for legacies of dead men's ſhoes, but buy new pumps to dance at the four weddings of us two.

sp.speaker: Capt. C.
sp.p: What ſays my lovely Julia? but let things go as they will, I'll give an entertainment at Tilts! and who knows but Cupid and Bacchus may light the torch of Hymen!

sp.speaker: Parrots.
sp.p: Yes, when my dowager gets a ſup in her eye, ſhe'll be able to ſee all my perfections double—and while the bottle goes round, my only imitations ſhall be to'take off my glaſs!

lg.head: Chorus.
lg.l: Merry I, ſo you ſing,

sp.speaker: COLIN.
sp.l: Here I've eat fine wheat ears,
Sop'd in ſea my neat ears;

lg.head: Chorus.
lg.l: Merry I ſo you ſing, &c.

lg.head: Chorus.
lg.l: Merry I, ſo you ſing, &c.

sp.speaker: CYPRESS.
sp.l: Vex'd, I'll make my will tho'

lg.head: Chorus.
lg.l: Merry I, ſo you ſing, &c.

lg.head: Chorus.
lg.l: Merry I, ſo you ſing, &c.

lg.head: Chorus.
lg.l: Merry I, ſo you ſing, &c.
